author: ANDREW GROSS
title: NHL: 10 players or coaches who will be watched closely this season - Hockey
text:
The NHL season opens on Wednesday night.
The scrutiny has already begun, in advance, for many.
So here’s an alphabetical look at 10 players or coaches who will be watched closely this season:
* Frederik Andersen: Many, including both hockey reporters at this newspaper, have picked the Ducks to win the Stanley Cup. In order for that to happen, their goalie has to be spot on after going 35-12-5 with a 2.38 goals-against average last season. Plus, Andersen is being pushed in the organization by John Gibson, who’ll start the season in the AHL to further his development.
* Matt Beleskey: The ex-Duck left wing cashed in on his 22 goals and 10 assists last season with a five-year, $19 million deal with the Bruins. Considering Beleskey, 27, had never scored more than 11 goals prior to last season, it’s a $19 million gamble.
* Jamie Benn: Nothing but great things is expected from the Stars center, who led the NHL with 87 points last season. But the preseason MVP candidate also is a lynchpin to the Stars’ heightened expectations with the acquisitions of goalie Antti Niemi, left wing Patrick Sharp and defenseman Johnny Oduya, all recent Cup winners with the Blackhawks.
* Devan Dubnyk: The goalie, 29, never proved to be a No. 1 in previous stops with the Oilers and Coyotes but, traded to the Wild last season, he went 27-9-2 with a 1.78 goals-against average. The Wild rewarded him with a six-year, $26 million deal, betting they saw the real Dubnyk.
* Mike Green: Head injuries slowed his career with the Capitals, where he was once one of the most dangerous offensive-minded defensemen in the NHL. Still only 29 and now with the Red Wings, whose streak of 24 straight playoff appearances could be in jeopardy, Green is getting a fresh start.
* Ken Hitchcock: A slow start will almost certainly cost Hitchcock his job as Blues coach.
* Claude Julien: Ditto for the Bruins coach.
* Phil Kessel: Joining the Penguins, he could score 50 goals on Sidney Crosby’s right wing. Or he could frustrate a third organization after indifferent performances with the Maple Leafs and Bruins.
* Ryan O’Reilly: Legal issues aside, the 24-year-old ex-Avalanche center will be under plenty of pressure with the new-look Sabres, now coached by Dan Bylsma. The Sabres are paying him $52.5 million over seven seasons to be a leader.
* Cam Talbot: Can Henrik Lundqvist’s former understudy, 27, traded to the Oilers, turn his first chance to be a team’s No. 1 goalie into a lucrative new contract while backstopping the new "it" team with No. 1 overall pick Connor McDavid?
